title: How to Make Walnut and Pecan Torte

steps.headline: Line the pan with parchment paper.
Beat egg yolks in a large bowl at medium-high speed for 1 minute.
Add in the sugar gradually.
steps.description: Keep beating until thick and lemon colored.

steps.headline: Add in walnut, pecan, and bread crumbs.
Get a separate bowl and beat egg whites and cream of tartar at medium-high speed until stiff but not dry.
Fold 1/4 of the egg whites into the batter, and then fold in the remaining egg whites.
Pour the batter into the springform pan.
steps.description: Bake for 40 minutes in the oven until a toothpick inserted into the center comes out clean. Let cool in the pan on a rack.

steps.headline: Bring 1″ water in a skillet to a simmer.
In a large stainless steel bowl, whisk together egg whites, sugar, water, and cream of tartar with low speed.
steps.description: Place the bowl inside the skillet and keep whisking until the mixture is 140ºF. Then using a high speed, beat until the mixture reaches 160ºF.

steps.headline: Remove the bowl from the skillet and add the vanilla.
steps.description: Continue beating on high speed for 3-5 more minutes, to help cool the batter down. The batter should hold glossy peaks.

steps.headline: In another large bowl, beat the butter until creamy.
steps.description: Transfer a large dollop of egg whites batter into the butter and keep beating until well combined. Transfer the remaining egg whites batter to the butter mixture in two batches. Keep beating until mixture is smooth and fluffy.

steps.headline: Stir in the dissolved coffee into the cream and mix with a spatula until well blended.
Since the torte is quite thin, first cut in half using a serrated knife.
Spread some of the coffee cream onto the top of one of the torte halves so the the other halves can be placed on top of it.
Completely cover the torte with the coffee cream, setting aside some cream for decoration purposes.
Place the saved cream into a piping bag.
steps.description: Use the head of your choice and decorate away. Perhaps add some maraschino cherries to get a more festive looking cake, but this is completely optional.

text: The cake Line the pan with parchment paper. Preheat oven to 350ºF. Beat egg yolks in a large bowl at medium-high speed for 1 minute.  Add in the sugar gradually. Keep beating until thick and lemon colored. Add in walnut, pecan, and bread crumbs. Stir until well blended. Get a separate bowl and beat egg whites and cream of tartar at medium-high speed until stiff but not dry.  Fold 1/4 of the egg whites into the batter, and then fold in the remaining egg whites.  Pour the batter into the springform pan. Bake for 40 minutes in the oven until a toothpick inserted into the center comes out clean. Let cool in the pan on a rack. Coffee buttercream Bring 1″ water in a skillet to a simmer.  In a large stainless steel bowl, whisk together egg whites, sugar, water, and cream of tartar with low speed. Place the bowl inside the skillet and keep whisking until the mixture is 140ºF. Then using a high speed, beat until the mixture reaches 160ºF. Remove the bowl from the skillet and add the vanilla. Continue beating on high speed for 3-5 more minutes, to help cool the batter down. The batter should hold glossy peaks. In another large bowl, beat the butter until creamy. Transfer a large dollop of egg whites batter into the butter and keep beating until well combined. Transfer the remaining egg whites batter to the butter mixture in two batches. Keep beating until mixture is smooth and fluffy. Stir in the dissolved coffee into the cream and mix with a spatula until well blended.  Assembling the cake Since the torte is quite thin, first cut in half using a serrated knife.  Spread some of the coffee cream onto the top of one of the torte halves so the the other halves can be placed on top of it.  Completely cover the torte with the coffee cream, setting aside some cream for decoration purposes.  Place the saved cream into a piping bag. Use the head of your choice and decorate away. Perhaps add some maraschino cherries to get a more festive looking cake, but this is completely optional. Finished.
